update.description:
This is a TCP server class. I've included some instructions and a description in Server.hh

Let me know if something is not clear, does not work or you have suggestions.

@nima_sh Take a look at the code. Your s-expression parser should implement a `Parse()` method for reading s-expressions from the socket. Let me know if you have any questions.

The coverage is 83% because there's some code difficult to cover. E.g.: When a socket option fails, etc. As far as I know all the code besides these corner cases is exercised in the test.
update.title: TCP server

content.raw: I see, thanks for the explanation.
content.html: I see, thanks for the explanation.

As far as I know the :: prefix is for specifying a global scope. Let's say you have something like this:

void Send()
{
  ...
}

class MyClass
{
  void Send()
  {
    ...
  }

  void F1()
  {
    ::Send();
  }   

  void F2()
  {
    Send()
  }
};

MyClass obj;

// This method is executing the global Send() function.
obj.F1();

// This method is executing the Send() member function.
obj.F2();

So, not sure about using it here unless there's a conflict with other send() method.

content.raw: Not for now :)
content.html: Not for now :)

You can see an example of this in the NewClient test. When the server is instantiated we pass in a parser instance as an argument. This parser is an instance of TrivialSocketParser that I wrote for the test. The parse() method of this class is automatically executed when there's activity on the socket. If you look at the parse() method you can see that there's a line: 

EXPECT_EQ(std::string(buffer), content);

that verifies the data received from the client.

content.raw:
1) The dashed box is to indicate that it is a pointer to a non member variable of the plugin.

2) I have updated the diagram to reflect the actual architecture for Agent and Team.

3) The socket ids will be kept in the agent object itself, it is the Effector class that will set them.

4) The Effector class can inherit from SocketParser and implement its interface.

5) The socket ids will be kept track by the Agent object
content.html:
1) The dashed box is to indicate that it is a pointer to a non member variable of the plugin.

2) I have updated the diagram to reflect the actual architecture for Agent and Team.

3) The socket ids will be kept in the agent object itself, it is the Effector class that will set them.

4) The Effector class can inherit from SocketParser and implement its interface.

5) The socket ids will be kept track by the Agent object

content.raw:
![server architecture.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/2822619674-server_architecture.png)

### Legend: ###

**[Grey box]** 

RobocupPlugin: This is the master object of the plugin that creates all the other objects. It is the only object that has access to the gazebo world model. It will call the update functions of its member objects and also update the gazebo world model accordingly

**[Arrows]**

Arrows with square ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a non-pointer member variable.

Arrows with round ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a pointer member variable.

Arrows with dashed lines indicate a pointer to another object's method.

**[Block with dashed lines]** Gazebo world object: This is an external object that the plugin has a pointer to.

**[Colored blocks with solid lines: Each of these are an object that exists as members of the RobocupPlugin]**

GameState: This object keeps track of the state of the game and rule violations and an update method to do that. It has two important member objects: Agents and Teams. 

Perceptor: This object fills in the Agent Percept container with the update method. It also is responsible for sending a s-expression string to the server using the send method.

Effector: This object parses any s-expression sent by the server using the onconnect callback. It is reponsible for updating Agent Action container via its update method and keep track of which agent id is associated with socket id.

Server: The server manages connections from the client. When it receives data on a tcp socket, it calls the onconnect method in the Effector object. When the Perceptor finishes updating, it calls the send method and the server sends the data back to the client through the socket.

Agent Action/Percept: These are simply container classes for various perception and effector information. They do not have any methods. Each Agent object has an agent action and agent percept object
content.html:
Legend:

[Grey box]

RobocupPlugin: This is the master object of the plugin that creates all the other objects. It is the only object that has access to the gazebo world model. It will call the update functions of its member objects and also update the gazebo world model accordingly

[Arrows]

Arrows with square ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a non-pointer member variable.

Arrows with round ends indicate that the object it is pointing to is a pointer member variable.

Arrows with dashed lines indicate a pointer to another object's method.

[Block with dashed lines] Gazebo world object: This is an external object that the plugin has a pointer to.

[Colored blocks with solid lines: Each of these are an object that exists as members of the RobocupPlugin]

GameState: This object keeps track of the state of the game and rule violations and an update method to do that. It has two important member objects: Agents and Teams.

Perceptor: This object fills in the Agent Percept container with the update method. It also is responsible for sending a s-expression string to the server using the send method.

Effector: This object parses any s-expression sent by the server using the onconnect callback. It is reponsible for updating Agent Action container via its update method and keep track of which agent id is associated with socket id.

Server: The server manages connections from the client. When it receives data on a tcp socket, it calls the onconnect method in the Effector object. When the Perceptor finishes updating, it calls the send method and the server sends the data back to the client through the socket.

Agent Action/Percept: These are simply container classes for various perception and effector information. They do not have any methods. Each Agent object has an agent action and agent percept object

content.raw:
I was busy with my pull request and its documentation such that I have not seen your comment about the effector class:
1- I will check agent.hh, and the procedure of AddAgent and RemoveAgent. I did not explicitly test the callbacks during my tests, however I am using now the socket id in the effector's onconnect callback for Parser_test. I think for initializing an agent by using onconnect callback, The effector class should also check the client message and check if Scene message has been sent or not.
2- Currently we only update the effectors values in current cycle.
3- I will implement say effector part.

content.raw:
Thanks for the quick update. A few considerations before you start making a new diagram:

* Shouldn't the `Gazebo World Model` be outside of the plugin, and the plugin has a pointer to it? (instead of a dashed box)

* Still related to my previous comment, it would be nice to portray the clients from outside connecting to the Server like in Carlos's Server description.

* If `Agent` and `Team` are members of `GameState`, shouldn't they be outside of it and connected with a square arrow? Alternatively, `AgentPercept` and `AgentActions` could be boxes inside `Agent`. Does this make sense?

* The relation between the `Server`, the `Perceptor` and the `AgentPercept` is not very clear to me. `Perceptor` will separately fill the `GameState::Agent::AgentPercept` and send it to the clients via the `Server`, right? Since the `Agent` has the `SocketID`, wouldn't it make more sense to follow this path: `Perceptor -> GameState::Agent::AgentPercept -> Server::Send` ? And where do the outgoing s-expressions get created?

* If the `Effector` is responsible for parsing the incoming s-expressions, where does the `SocketParser` go? Wouldn't it be better to keep all s-expression outside of the `Effector` class so if maybe in the future we change the type of communication we can keep the same interface with the `Effector`? Or did I get something wrong here?

* Maybe this is something which you've already decided with @caguero , but I'm not sure why it is the `Effector`'s responsibility to keep track of `SocketIDs`, since these will should be needed by the `Perceptor` as well, right? Maybe I'm misunderstanding the role of the `SocketParser`.
content.html:
Thanks for the quick update. A few considerations before you start making a new diagram:

  • Shouldn't the Gazebo World Model be outside of the plugin, and the plugin has a pointer to it? (instead of a dashed box)

  • Still related to my previous comment, it would be nice to portray the clients from outside connecting to the Server like in Carlos's Server description.

  • If Agent and Team are members of GameState, shouldn't they be outside of it and connected with a square arrow? Alternatively, AgentPercept and AgentActions could be boxes inside Agent. Does this make sense?

  • The relation between the Server, the Perceptor and the AgentPercept is not very clear to me. Perceptor will separately fill the GameState::Agent::AgentPercept and send it to the clients via the Server, right? Since the Agent has the SocketID, wouldn't it make more sense to follow this path: Perceptor -> GameState::Agent::AgentPercept -> Server::Send ? And where do the outgoing s-expressions get created?

  • If the Effector is responsible for parsing the incoming s-expressions, where does the SocketParser go? Wouldn't it be better to keep all s-expression outside of the Effector class so if maybe in the future we change the type of communication we can keep the same interface with the Effector? Or did I get something wrong here?

  • Maybe this is something which you've already decided with @caguero , but I'm not sure why it is the Effector's responsibility to keep track of SocketIDs, since these will should be needed by the Perceptor as well, right? Maybe I'm misunderstanding the role of the SocketParser.

content.raw:
1- The server should tell the effector what the socket id is via the onconnect callback. The effector will then access the gamestate object, create a new agent by calling the AddAgent method and then associate that new agent (using the AgentId type, which is defined in Agent.hh) with the socket id. When the ondisconnect callback is called, the effector will also remove the agent from gamestate by calling the RemoveAgent method

2- We just need the effector values sent in the current cycle.

3- The effector should update the AgentSay member variable in gamestate when it receives a say message. The perceptor will handle sending the hear message back to the server.
content.html:
1- The server should tell the effector what the socket id is via the onconnect callback. The effector will then access the gamestate object, create a new agent by calling the AddAgent method and then associate that new agent (using the AgentId type, which is defined in Agent.hh) with the socket id. When the ondisconnect callback is called, the effector will also remove the agent from gamestate by calling the RemoveAgent method

2- We just need the effector values sent in the current cycle.

3- The effector should update the AgentSay member variable in gamestate when it receives a say message. The perceptor will handle sending the hear message back to the server.

content.html: should it be the effector class that contains a map from agent ids to socket ids?

@jasonzliang , could you describe each block in a few words? Nothing too fancy, just a general description for us to have a better idea of what each block means.

For example, in the previous diagram, Agents referred to clients (users) outside of the server, but here you added an agent box inside of GameState and I'm not sure what that means.

I think it would also be nice to capture @caguero 's ASCII art in this diagram.

content.raw:
I have updated the server architecture slightly. Nima you should note that there is a container class which you need to put the updated effector information into, namely the agent actions class. The effector class should have a pointer to GameState object, which in turn has Agent objects, which in turn has the Agent Action objects. You can take a look at the interface for gamestate and agents here: 

[#!/osrf/robocup3ds/src/eaf5981a5c336ea6f004f7f0296876268cac94fd/include/robocup3ds/Agent.hh?at=jliang_model](#!/osrf/robocup3ds/src/eaf5981a5c336ea6f004f7f0296876268cac94fd/include/robocup3ds/Agent.hh?at=jliang_model)


[#!/osrf/robocup3ds/src/eaf5981a5c336ea6f004f7f0296876268cac94fd/include/robocup3ds/GameState.hh?at=jliang_model](#!/osrf/robocup3ds/src/eaf5981a5c336ea6f004f7f0296876268cac94fd/include/robocup3ds/GameState.hh?at=jliang_model)
content.html:
